user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_close:
```c
int32 OS_close(osal_id_t filedes)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericClose_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_close:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided function and the related type/macro definitions. There are no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the shown code. In particular:
- No compiler-specific keywords or attributes such as __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, __builtin_*, typeof (GNU extension), or other vendor-specific extensions are present.
- No statement expressions ({ ... }) or nested functions (GCC extension) are used.
- No variable length arrays, designated initializers, or other C99/C11 features that are compiler-dependent appear here; the typedefs (int32 from int32_t, uint32, osal_id_t) are standard typedef uses based on stdint types, not extensions.
- The forward typedef (typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t), macros (OS_SUCCESS), and normal function calls/returns are standard C.

Given the snippet and the additional definitions provided, there are no fragments that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (prohibition of language extensions). If there are other files or usage of compiler-specific pragmas/attributes elsewhere, those would need separate review.
